QA 29 Periodic Flushing / Copper Protection Test Sheet
column8: QA 29 Periodic Flushing / Copper Protection Test Sheet

column2: ITP QA 29 Periodic Flushing / Copper Protection Test Sheet

Copper systems are failing in the construction industry due to stagnate water being left in both hot and cold copper pipelines. Copper needs to form a protective layer of copper oxide on the internal surface which is formed by the contact with fresh aerated and oxygenated water. Periodic flushing of the systems is the only way to ensure this occurs.
The purpose of this ITP is to help you create the strategy to get this water out and replaced with fresh water every four weeks.

column3: Ring main –Single point for flushing; the entire loop can be achieved in a maximum 10-minute flush., Non ring mains – Any copper sub-branch from the main feed requires individual flush time of 5 minutes (an example of this would be a corridor feed)., Short branches of copper that feed rehau do not need individual flushing., Multi storey projects will require flushing on each level. Starting from the top and working your way down

column2: Which fixtures are being used to flush the system (Point of connection and point of discharge):
Has the schematic / layout of the flushed zone been highlighted, attached and flush points nominated.
Is the flushed water clear with no visible debris or dirt. If NO, discuss with project foreman and or head office on why this might be the case.
Have you set a reminder for the next flushing of this pipework?
Have the hot and cold been interconnected for flushing purposes?
Date for next flushing (Flushing to be performed every 4 weeks):

column8: VHH - Water Protection ITP (V.090421)

column2: Part 1 - VHH Periodic Flushing / Copper Protection Test Sheet

Copper systems are failing in the construction industry due to issues relating to design, water quality, the management of water during construction, long term maintenance of buildings with issues arising from building management team not following protocols outlined at hand over. Stagnant water being left in both hot and cold copper pipelines have been deemed to have been a contributing factor to recent copper failures. Copper needs to form a protective layer of copper oxide on the internal surface which is formed by the contact with fresh aerated and oxygenated water

Geschke Plumbing in consultation with John Holland & AECOM have put forward a proposal of periodic flushing of the systems during construction to mitigate the stagnant water issues that have arisen in the construction industry. The purpose of this ITP is to help create a strategy to ensure water is flowing through the piping system and flushed at nominated locations
Plans to flush to be submitted to John Holland prior to any flushing occurring on site
Flushing Details (Flushing to be Completed with Water ONLY)
Stage of Flushing During the Project
1. Initial flush after installation of pipework and prior to Quality Control Pressure Test Report (Geschke QA 6)
3. Periodic flushing during construction (to be completed every 4 weeks – in line with AS 4809 clause 6.2.9)
4. Periodic flushing from final flush until PC (to be completed every 4 weeks – in line with AS 4809 clause 6.2.9)
Time & Type of Flushing (As per reference table below)
5. Ring main –Single point for flushing; the entire loop can be achieved in a maximum 10-minute flush
6. Non ring mains – Any copper sub-branch from the main feed requires individual flush time of 5 minutes (an example of this would be a corridor feed)
7. Short branches of copper that feed rehau do not need individual flushing
Which fixtures are being used to flush the system (Point of Connection & Point of Discharge)
a. Has the schematic / layout of the flushed zone been highlighted, attached and flush points nominated
b. Is the flushed water clear with no visible debris or dirt. If NO, discuss with project foreman and or head office on why this might be the case
c. Have you set a reminder for the next flushing of this pipework
Date for next flushing (Flushing to be performed every 4 weeks at a minimum)
NOTE: The table flushing time is based on 100 metres of pipework discharging through 16mm nozzle at 350KPa
Stage of water quality testing during the project
1. Periodic water quality testing during construction (to be completed every 3 months)
2. Water quality testing post final flush
a. Geschke and John Holland management informed of sample / testing
b. Has the schematic / location of the sample collection been highlighted, attached, and nominated
c. Sample captured as per laboratory requirements
d. Time and date of sample recorded
Date for next Water Quality Sample (Water quality testing to be performed every 3 months at a minimum during construction)
Disinfection Checks - Pass once below completed
a. Geschke and John Holland management informed of disinfection with plan provided
b. Has disinfection occurred for 6 hours as per AS/NZS 3500.1 appendix I
c. Time and date of disinfection
d. Flush all levels and branches until chlorination levels have reached safe chlorine levels as per Australian drinking water guidelines.

column2: QA 6C - Qaulity Control Flow Test and Compliance Report - Safety Showers and Eyewash:
Flow Rate and Pressure as per Australian Standard 4775
Safety Shower - The flow is to be at a minimum 75.7 litres/minute at 210KPa
Eyewash - The flow is to be at a minimum 1.5Litres/minute at 210KPa
Pressure set on each floor: KPA
Safety Shower or Eye Wash Valve Open
Safety shower is installed between 2083mm and 2438mm
Spray pattern ensuring is at a minimum of 508mm in diameter at 1524mm above the surface
Date of Completion of Satisfactory Test

column8: QA 18 - Gasket Installation

column2: Gasket Contact Surface Finish on Flange:
1. Galvanised nuts and bolts – must use good quality lubricating oil on threads
2. Below Ground Galvanised nuts and bolts– must denzo and plastic wrap full flange and cover bolts
3. Stainless steel nuts and bolts – must use anti seize / molybond on threads – must return 24 hrs later to tighten in sequence and required torque

4. Galvanised nuts and bolts on stainless steel flanges / backing rings - Thinsulators (insulating top hats) or insulating washer with thin PE sleeve must be used, and complete flange must be denzo wrapped with plastic protection

5. Stainless Steel nuts and bolts on galvanised steel flanges / backing rings - Thinsulators (insulating top hats) or insulating washer with thin PE sleeve must be used, and complete flange must be denzo wrapped with plastic protection
6. Zinc bolts, nuts and washers rust when used externally – use galvanised

Visually examine and clean flanges, bolts, nuts and washers. Replace components if necessary. Alignment of flange faces is very important and maintain support of the flange, pipework and valve at all times

Lubricate bolts, nuts AND flange surface AROUND BOLT HOLES, not on flange/gasket surface, or use hardened steel washers. Use anti-seize on stainless steel threads and nuts or on galvanised bolts and nuts lightly oil with good quality lubricating oil. Insert bolts in locations 1 to 4 as indicated in the below diagrams.
Install new gasket. DO NOT REUSE OLD GASKET, OR USE MULTIPLE GASKETS. Gaskets for water applications must be EPDM potable water gasket PN16 type. Gaskets for gas need to be AGA and GPL approved
Number bolts in cross-pattern sequence according to the appropriate sketch below with a marker pen, black or white

IMPORTANT! HAND TIGHTEN; then PRE-TIGHTEN BOLTS to 7Nm torque, but DO NOT EXCEED 20% of Target Torque. Target torque is required to be supplied by Gasket manufacturer / supplier – seek from GPL foreman
Use the appropriate cross-pattern tightening sequence in the sketch below for Rounds 1,2 and 3 and/or Round 4 (each sequence constitutes a “Round”)
* Refer to gasket manufacturer spec with torque chart on next page and GPL advice
Lubricate, Hand Tighten, Pre-Tighten bolts (5% of final torque) (as mentioned in item 5 above)

column5: 1st torque value in torque chart* (20% of final torque)
2nd torque value in torque chart* (50% of final torque)
3rd torque value in torque chart* (75% of final torque)

column2:
Check gap around the circumference between each of these rounds, measured at every other bolt. If the gap is not reasonably
 uniform around the circumference, make the appropriate adjustments be selective bolt tightening before proceeding.

Final Rotational Round – 100% of Final Torque (same as Round 3 or 4 above). Use ROTATIONAL, clockwise tightening sequence starting with Bolt No.1, for one complete round and continue by selective bolt tightening before proceeding.
Short-term bolt preload loss can occur between four to twenty-four hours after initial tightening due to bolt relaxation. Consider retightening to help recover this loss.
